file_content.text: You've increased our understanding of this region and potentially saved many lives. Well done, my friend.
My scanner's memory is already full? Perfect timing. I'll collate your data with my own readings and analyze them together.
Hmm... it seems the droids were indeed built for war. Twenty thousand years later, they still pursue their primary function. How sad.
These ancient droids were soldiers in Tython's great Force Wars--a time before there were Jedi, Sith or even a Republic.
I've never heard of these "Force Wars."
Force Wars?
It was the first conflict between Force users--a horrific battle between light and darkness that lasted for a hundred years.
Quite a revelation.
I almost got killed over a war that ended millennia ago?
What a waste of my time.
That is why Jedi continually strive for peace. Once a war begins, it is difficult to end.
According to the droid logs, Kaleth was a stronghold of the dark side's forces. They made their last stand here.
As they died, the dark siders activated the droids as a doomsday weapon--hoping to ensure the light side's destruction as well.
For doomsday droids, they sure fall apart easy.
They don't seem so tough.
I doubt either of us will hold up nearly as well after twenty thousand years. These machines were quite menacing for their epoch.
Clearly, the light side survived these doomsday weapons.
The droids failed.
Indeed--and went on to found our Jedi Order. To think what might have been, if the dark siders' plans had succeeded....
Do you have a plan for them?
The Council must deliberate and decide what should be done about the droids. It isn't up to us.
Well, have fun with that.
I'll consult the Jedi Council at once about this. You've been extraordinarily helpful.
By your efforts, we see Kaleth in a fresh light. I will commend you to the Council.
Continue with your tasks. Make your Masters proud.
Farewell, Jedi. May the Force be with you.
I've delayed you enough. I know how important the work you and Orgus do is. Give him my best.
I've delayed you enough, Padawan. Give Master Yuon my best wishes.
Use the scanner on any Tythonian droids you encounter--and take extra care in those ruins.
Here, examine this droid's cognitive unit I recovered from the ruins. Twenty-thousand years old, yet still functional. Our forebears built things to last.
What happened to the rest of the droid's parts?
Where's the droid's body?
Regrettably, I was forced to dismantle it with my lightsaber.
Are you saying the Jedi's ancestors built this?
Forebears?
Indeed--which makes the behavior of these machines all the more baffling.
That's amazing.
A shame the cognitive unit's owner had to be destroyed. It was a magnificent machine, but quite hostile.
Old junk? Who cares?
Are you not familiar with the ancient machines inhabiting these ruins? They're a great mystery.
The ruins of Lower Kaleth are filled with droids constructed during Tython's original colonization by the galaxy's first Force users.
We don't know the Tythonian droids' purpose--only that they attack anyone who enters the ruins. My mission is to learn why.
Why not simply wipe out all the droids?
Not to destroy them?
If we can reason with the droids, we stand to learn much about Tython's past.
What kind of damage can these droids do to people?
Anyone been hurt?
We've had several serious injuries. Left unchecked, the droids are going to kill someone. We can't let it come to that.
Whatever you say.
Wait, please. These droids are growing increasingly lethal. I could use your assistance dealing with them.
It's been millennia since the Tythonian droids were memory-wiped. Their programming lies buried amid trillions of accumulated databits.
I've constructed a scanner to analyze the droids' cognitive units for command protocols, but I need several samplings to sort through the static.
I'll get those samplings for you in no time, Master Till'in.
Let me take care of that.
Good. This will greatly accelerate my efforts to solve this mystery and make the ruins safe.
You need an assistant, right?
You passed your Jedi trials with ease. I know you can handle yourself in the ruins.
Your Master has great confidence in your abilities, as do I. This task won't be simple, but I know you'll succeed.
Sounds like a dull chore.
Until we understand why the ancient Tythonian droids are attacking us, these ruins won't be safe. Surely that's a problem worth solving?
Oh, all right.
Good. I'd hate to think you didn't feel some responsibility to the rest of the order.
Fair enough.
I'm glad you agree.
Take this scanner. When you encounter Tythonian droids in Lower Kaleth, disable them and scan the remains.
Bring the scanner back to me when its memory is full, so that I can analyze the data. Good luck.
By another. [Refuse quest]
Very well. Thank you again for delivering Padawan Fia's message. Goodbye.
Tython's most promising newcomers visit me together? A rare honor, indeed.
Greetings, Padawan--but now I see I am mistaken, you have already completed your Jedi trials. Well done.
Welcome, Padawan to Orgus Din. Your Master speaks highly of your potential.
Ah, Master Yuon's new Padawan. A great Jedi-in-the-making, by all accounts. Greetings.
Padawan Fia sends her regards--and this holorecording.
Know someone named Fia?
The poor girl--no doubt apologizing again. She nearly shot me when I approached her on Raxus Prime.
Someone asked me to deliver a message.
I have something for you.
Oh dear. Another one?
Good thing there aren't children around--you'd scare them to death.
You're ugly! [Give message]
Children are never frightened of me--or perhaps they're simply more polite than adults.
Let's see what you've brought me... ah yes. Fia. The poor girl is still apologizing for shooting at me on Raxus Prime.
I forget how violently some humans react when first meeting my species. I don't understand why they always seem to shoot before thinking.
You seem to have survived the encounter.
At least you weren't hurt.
Luckily, Fia's aim was unbalanced by her fear.
Don't ask me.
Indeed. Ah, well--a riddle to be pondered some other time.
Who knows why humans do anything?
Humans are strange.
Now, now. Let us embrace tolerance. Not all beings are as enlightened as we are.
Maybe because you're a hideous monster?
Isn't it obvious?
Mind yourself, young one. While your honesty is admirable, your tone lacks respect.
It was kind of you to deliver this holorecording, though I should gently instruct Padawan Fia to stop interrupting my work. Speaking of which....
Excuse me, Jedi. I must analyze these data readings.
Take care in the ruins of Kaleth, Padawan. The area is hazardous to all who enter.
Tython is a dangerous world even for Jedi. Maintain your visual scanning at all times.
